DIV1.P: THE Second-Sighted Highlander: OR, PREDICTIONS AND Foretold EVENTS: Especially about the PEACE.
BEING Ten New Visions for the Year 1713.
rinted for, and Sold by J. Baker in Pater∣noster-Row, Londn.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PREFACE BY THE PUBLISHER:
DIV1.P: THE Ancient experienc'd Per∣son who in his Meditations of hat shall succeed in this Age, has old such surprizing Things, and who ving oblig'd us to conceal his Name, e call the Highlander with the econd Sight, hath been very back∣ard this Year to give us his Notions Events; but being very much impor∣d. he sent to us (the Publishers of is Book) the following Letter; which thought fit to Publish, as a very d Introduction to the Work it self.

DIV1.HEAD: To my FRIENDS who sh Read or Print my Meditations the Times now in Sight.
DIV1.P: COncerning what shall come to pass the ensuing, he who foretold you so m Things in the last two Years, was reso to foretell you no more: But behold the Vision lowing, which he must not resist.

IN the Mountains of the abandon'd North, with Inhospitable Snows, where the quering Armies never tread, and even the S it self would find nothing to devour, WE Happy because of Misery: Secure because of verty: Free because out of the reach of those make the World Slaves. WE enjoy Rest by ha no Advantage for Labour, and having nothing to sess worth a War: WE possess all in Peace: In t remoter Corners We nevertheless by an incomm cable and unknown Method discern what YE act upon the more famous Part of the World's S South, are doing, and shall do: WE see wit Gazees and printed Accounts, the Events of and Peace; the Marchings of Armies, Sailing Fleets; my, the Cabinets of Princes, Counci
War, and Consultations of the grand Assemblies of the World are not conceald from us. In my tra∣versing the waste and barren Mounts of my Country, I see Mists crowning distant Mountains, and march∣ing to shock and engage each other, flaming Meterors dart this Way, rise, fall, shoot and flash; direct, oblique, prone, perpend, and pointing to each other: Moving Air describes in (to others invisible) small and exactly shap'd Clouds, the very Faces, Shapes, Names and Distinctions of such Persons, Nations, Towns, Cities and People of whom those Mists, Meteors, and other Clouds represent the Actions: Darkness it self forms the Posture of things by which WE see, and every Cloud is filld with Hieroglyphicks for the Assistance of this uncouth Attainment called SECOND SIGHT.

In this Manner Peace, War, Life, Death, Fate, Catastrophe, Plague, Dearth, Plenty, Victory, Loss, Storms, Blasts, Tempests, and universal Event is more easily seen by Ʋ S, than any Calculation from Views of Stars, Constellations, Motions or Positi∣ons of Heavenly Bodies can discern: As these Views have signified then in my Observe for the Year co∣ming, take them as follows.

DIV2.HEAD: First VISION.
DIV2.P:
IN the black of the Night, Lomon-top being two Thirds dismal, came a light Gleam from the Ea, thro' which, piercing Sight discovers, that in the Counci of the Northern World much Confusion happens in the first of the Year about Peace and War; the Crowns
and Powers engaged against F—e inveigh against one of their own Ally'd Branches, and being Exas∣perate at that Power for what they call Betray∣ing them, consult how to make Peace themselves, and Avenge themselves of those who dealt Trea∣cherously with them, but Power fails; I saw the Mu∣ster-Roll of their devised Power too weak, so they content themselves with Recording, that separating Power in all their Archives as the most perfidious Nation upon Earth, whether justly or no the Vision says not.

A Voice I heard not, but in Capitals of bright Air were written on a Cloud at inconceivable Di∣iance, such Words (tho' in Celestial Characters) as these, The perfidious Nation trodden down of those she Saved, and laugh'd at by those she Betrayed. In the Measure of Time observ'd by our Ancestors from the Degree of Brightness on the Cloud in the Center of Vision, this Appearance signifis twelve Years, eleven Lunar Months, some Days, e'er it come to pass.

The bright little Body of Cloud which represented Peace moved on, but stopp'd before the Place de∣sign'd for its Rest; so no Peace seems to be yet ripe enough to be declared in Europe, whether Ge∣neral or Separate.

The North Point of Mac-ders over the great Lough, lourd three Days and a half: There I see three Months and half of this coming Year the Nations of Europe shall prepare for War, tho' Peace be in their Words, and I fear even then, another Year of Blood e'er the Quiet of Europe be Established, the louring Cloud ending in black, not bright, shows t
my Sight, that the War must go on a while; Britain shares not in the War, nor Holland much; but as they lose no Blood, whether She gains Honour, latet Anguis, Time shows not yet.

All the Councils of Europe busied in oppressing the Nations by Taxes: This I saw in an infinite Ap∣pearance of Cloud representing the People of the World stripp'd Naked, and crowding together to get Food and Covering in Winter.

DIV2.HEAD: Second VISION.
DIV2.P: FER the Morning Sun rise, or the comfortles ay of Cold and Storm breaks in the howling Waste of the black High-Lands, I am call'd out to see a dancing Light dazzling and casting dismal Reflecti∣ons on the Seas, made also black by boisterous Winds. What sees the piercing Eye in this Glimmer of Mock-Day? I see there Strise and Envy; two She-Furies riding Victors among the Nations of Europe, and filling them with the Noxious Vapour of their stag∣nate Seed, impregnating the Passions, and embroiling the Councils of Europe.

The once United Powers jar, differ, envy, strive, each willing to make the best Terms they can in the Peace, which they all a edge themselves forc'd to agree to; but each jealous of one another, let one makes the Concessions which the other would make, to gain the same Advantages.

The like Effects of Strise and Envy among th Northern Confederates, who all incline to make a Peace with the Swees, but agree not with one another and lose thereby both the Occasion of a good Peace and the Advantage they seem'd to have by the War for the Swedes who seem to be Ruin'd, escape, and remain still formidable; they also begin to fin Friends among the Christian as well as Turkish Pow∣ers of Europe, who resolve to check the Ambition o the Muscovite.

Amber Clouds rising from the Dawn tells me by th Vision of their Figure, that the threatning Preparati∣ons of War in the North fill Europe with Apprheon that their Miseries are not at an End: But beyon all this, the pointed Eye saw a Calm with assure Lines of Peace written over the Angle of Even for the whole Year; signifying that this Year tha however finish the Strise of this part of the World but a Vista beyond all, shews that Peace shall neithe be pleasing or lasting.

The farther Part South of these Appearances assur me that the Strife of People among themselves: bate not in this Nation, and the Vision portend Blood, and much Confusion in the End of Things tho' not yet; some Tempests shall about the Mont of February terrifie these Parts, and Merchants su∣fer much Loss.

DIV2.HEAD: Third VISION.
DIV2.P:
THE Sun in its Rising with bright Clouds ga Leave to the fierce penetrating Sight te written in its Center the Fate of Nari in
cters of enamell'd Spots Chain-like, forming Let∣ers unintelligible, but to the Power of revers'd Opticks: Here the Vision reads a Crown'd Head iving up its Life, and giving Peace to its People by e Way of the Grave: Confusions follow in ma∣y Parts of the World: Bloody Characters writ∣n on the Left hand part of the Appearance tells , that the Western part of Europe begins now to ame; the French and Imperialists begin the War if they had cast off Thoughts of Peace; yet e Armies cannot be in their compleat Appear∣nce in the Field; Britain strives to prevent, but annot effectually do it yet, and Holland, tho' nwillingly, sits passive; Negotiations of a certain ower to oblige to Peace, are refused, and that otentate upbraided by common Assent of many Na∣ons with dishonourable Actions: Spots in the Sun escribe the Ignominy of Princes and Crown'd otentates, the worse by how much all the Pro∣edings contradict former Measures of the same ower with the same Persons nnd Parties, and in e same Cause.

Here in a clear Horizon appears the Genius of weden oppress'd with many Enemies, stript of many its Plumes, that is Possessions, grown despe∣te and raging, but naked and forsaken, yet ri∣ng by its own Virtue in the End: This, the ision tells me, shall end thus: The King of that ation finding it not impossible to embroil the East Europe in a War between the Turks and Mus∣vites in his Behalf, quitting the Territories of the urks, with an armed Force, appears again in Pole. his procures new Scenes of Blood and War; but e Swede prospers not till last of all, and remote.

Britain sits still, and engages not in Foreig Wars, by which the People obtain some Ease Taxes; but Civil Feuds embroil us; our brig Sun shines with many Spots, and all our Hem sphere suffers an Eclipse by the Intestine Quarre among contending Sides at Home; especially epect Troubles from the North of various Kinds.

Great Talk and private Attempts about Marc to make Way forthe Pretender, but that Fruit is n ripe, and some who pretend to pull it before is come to Perfection, make much of it Fall to t Ground in the shaking; two Great Men fall at th Time, by whom the Enemy have so many the few Friends.

DIV2.HEAD: Fourth VISION.
DIV2.P: THE Grey of the Morning, thick with Win and Clouds, forms Vapours in dismal Aspe over the great Lake of the floating Lands: T Islands swimming in Lomon shock and dash togther. The Vision sees Armies of Animated Part shocking together with such a Force, as entire sinks and overthrows One: Note, The Honest sin the Knavish swim; the evil Spirit Victor over t good; Power oppresses Right, and Liberty in certain Nation receives a great, and almost fat Blow.

In very Legible Characters to such whose Intenal Opticks are rightly employ'd, I read War no
egun in four Places in Europe: France receives ome Advantage, but is checqu'd by a flaming rince from the North-East; a great Person who avels Abroad on his private Occasions is courted embark in Europe's Quarrel, in behalf of some those he formerly assisted; as yet he declines.
Terror appears in the Vapours following the ; Mortality begins to threaten the World; by trembles, and Germany also, but the Season oung, the Day early, and the Sun not risen its Meridian.
Kindly Seasons promise well, plenty of Food Britain, and Scarcity Abroad gives us an Ad∣age which we know no more how to use, than to deserve, or be thankful for.

dd Doings in the Assemblies of the Estates of tain Country, juggling of Statesmen, and the nely surprising End of a Great Person about onths of April or May; some Action in the this time; on the Rhine great Motions, the War goes on faster than the Peace, ally on the Side of Spain and Italy; the seem to waver very much, and it may ll by this time conclude vigorously to stop ffusion of Blood: Spain weak, acts no∣but the French push in Catalonia, and the or unable to relieve his People there, com∣th some Things which he would not else some Blood drawn about the Rhine; a ction or two, and Loss on both Sides; mans suffer, but revive.

DIV2.HEAD: Fifth VISION.
DIV2.P: MOrning and Evening expose the Circles Vision, Midnight-Dark abating, the Li for the conceal'd Sight lie parallel at the S ting or Rising of the Sun, which now begins leave no Night in Parts so near the Pole as th are. From the Summit of an immense Mount lying East, come darting every Morning, R of Vision, which are perceptible only to th who see by Internal Perspective.

Here I see the Broils and bloody Content of the World are not at all abated, but in a ? remov'd from the Camp to the Cabinet; Fury and Animosity of People, and espe the Princes of the World, is exerted in their forming Interests, and strengthening them against one another more by New Confede than by Open War.

I see a Storm in the vast Nothern Cale Ocean, Seas rise against Seas with threa Bulk, and Waters gathering to the Battl sudden Accident arising from small Oc ill managed, shall cause Two great Ma Powers of Europe to threaten War against other, and Open Preparations on both Side it seem Impossible to be avoided, but ven over rules and averts the threatne struction for the present; how long, the says not.

The first publick Steps towards a General Peace are taken about this time, both Sides being by this time able to make some Estimate of the other's Strength, and the Events of War. A great Siege about this time, this alters the Affairs of the Emperor, if the Dutch, accepting the Cessation of Arms, with hold their Fleets, Catalonia must fall into the Hands of the French, and of the Spaniards of course, and the Imperial Army capitulate to be sent away: Count Staremberg is willing to have a parting Blow with the Spaniard, and makes one last Effort, but want of all things oppresseth the German Valour, and disappoints the well-laid Designs of the Count, tho an Experienc'd Ge∣neral as any in the World.

Thro' a bright Emanation the piercing Eye sees a black dismal Time, threatning Judgment, Mortality and Contagion, the legible Part spells Hamburgh, Hungary, Constantinople, Italy, Bre∣men, Pomeren; if the Plague visits not most of these Parts this Year, my Second Sight must fail more than I think it shall; let other nearer Parts Prepare for it.

DIV2.HEAD: Sixth VISION:
DIV2.P: THis Season, which it was expected should have finished the Plagues of Mankind re¦specting War and Bloodshed, affords u rather threatning Prospects of new Commotions; the Dutch, and some Princes of Germany arm a new, being alarm'd at some Proceedings which respect the Succession of Monarchs to some Do∣minions on this North part of the Globe; these Preparations shall put some on this Side in great Consternation, and others in great Expectation; nor does the Vision of this Season reach to the End of these New Affairs: WE, who in this Island have upon our Hands a Matter of the last Moment respecting the Succession of our Monarchs, cannot be without Concern in such an Affair, and if some Attempts are made to its Prejudice, they may be expected about the Months of June or July; let the People of Bri∣tain take need of pulling down with their own Hands their Securities: None can hurt them but themselves.

Heaven threatens, as far as the Power of dicta∣ted Vision extends, great Calamities upon the Face of the Earth about this time; War makes the least Haveok this Year, yet Blood flows plentifully in the North, no Accommodation can yet be made with the Swedes and the Musco∣vites; the Turk threatens, and the Muscovite pre∣pares for them; the Frontiers suffer dreadful Ra∣vages on both Sides, but Poland feels the Hea∣viest of the War: The King of Sweden now
oushes Home on every Side, and bids fair to reduce all his Enemies; a bloody Action in Po∣land.

Ʋtrecht is now the Scene of War: There the ate of Kingdoms seems to be absolutely deci∣ded, neither Side make any considerable Advantage of the War in the Field, yet some small Advances are made in the Treaties, and the several Pretensi∣ons of the Princes are so great, and their Inte∣ests so inconsistent with one another, that they some yet to no Conclusion, the Breach has been oo wide to be soon closed.

A Fight in the North between the Swedes and their Enemies; the Swedes have the Advantage, t with much Loss, which weakens them, and lines them to Treat again: Some new Friends the Swedish Interest appears, and France reatens the Muscovite, but has his Hands to ll yet.

DIV2.HEAD: Sventh VISION.
DIV2.P:
THE Glorious Show of Peace which appear'd in great Collections of bright Clouds in Eastern Heavens, have some time drawn to∣ther, and I hope still to be able to sing, Quiet on th, Good-will towards Men; but to my Amaze, they separate again, and retire each from other,
leaving a vast Chasm or Interval without Mesure, deep as the Sea, and black as the Abyss What can this signifie! Breach of Treaties, Di appointments among Allies and Confederates Interruption of the expected Blessing of Peac and all Sides making Appearance of farther Di contents, preparing as if they resolv'd to ope again the Breaches of Europe, and renew Wa and the Sword: Great Havock made in th North by bloody Actions more than One or Tw between the Poles and the Turks.

The Alarms which caused the Dutch Powers Arm, mention'd before, contribute to this amon the Nations; Britain shares this Year an uncomon Perturbation, Peace in appearance, but ternal Chagrin among her Nobles, Disconte and Fears among her Commons; Measures sh be taken in transacting under-hand to strength Interest on every Side, in case of a Rupture Home either by Mortality or otherwise: Gre Apprehensions in case of Demise of the Incu bent, that the Crown is in Bargain to a Forei Potentate, whose Power threatens the setting by Force on a Head which every one rejects; Event of these Dissatisfactions seem to threa Blood, but while God preserves one Reigni Life, these Shadows appear distant enough.

The Appearances of a War between Bri and the Dutch abate, and there rise up stre of Light, which make smooth the Face of Ocean where the Threathings of a Mari War were seen, yet Misunderstandings rem and leave ranckling behind unheal'd, which
be in Danger every Year of breaking out, unless more perfectly healed at the Conclusion of Ge∣neral Quiet in Europe.

Great Mortality about July among the Men of Rank and Degree in the World, among whom three Sovereigns go Hand in Hand to the great A∣yss, from whence no looking behind: The dark hreatning Appearance which gave a View of the Contagion in Europe, continues, and Multitudes re swept away.

Armies ravage Europe without Action, and nowing neither Peace or War by the Orders they receive, yet live at Discretion, and the oor People in View of Peace, feel all the Ca∣mities of War, even on both Sides.

DIV2.HEAD: Eighth VISION.
DIV2.P: F the usual Appearances of Peace shew any thing of Certainty, now they draw together ain, Britain having from the first laid down Arms, and making no Shew of taking them again, except to enforce the Peace She has ojected; Neighbouring Potentates find some ecessity of complying, and begin to close, but t without National Cursings and Imprecations ainst a certain Potentate, who they in loud eproachings charge with betraying the Cause uch they say they had undertaken, and sworn maintain.

The Combustions in the Heavens descending to fall in Cloud and Tempests, give our clear Second Sight a View of the Agitations which the Men of all Nations suffer at this time, and the Peace they seem to yield to become more grievous to them than the War; but Heaven over-rules and gives Peace to some People in a Judg∣ment for their Correction; for lo, all the Peace which shall appear, prevents not new Broils from breaking forth in the World, and the Great Men continue to tear one another in pieces.

Whensoever the Conclusion of what the Peo∣ple call Peace, appears among us, it deceives the Expectation of every Side; those who expect the Nation shall be effectually settled and quiet at Home by having Peace Abroad, and those who expect that new Wars shall immediately break out Abroad, are equally deceiv'd; the furious Agitation of Parties at Home rather encreases than abates by the Stop which is put to the War Abroad; strong siding against the Great Ones, quarrelling the Peace, impeaching the Integrity and Design of those who have brought it to this Length, as what has been a Ruin to the Mea∣sures formerly taken both at Home and Abroad; great and formal Accusations of Ill Practises against the publick Welfare involve several Great Persons on either Side, and these again embark Parties to their several Interests, the Heats rouz both Sides to terrible Attacks upon each other and Rabble decides the Controversie at last, to the unspeakable Distraction of the People.

The Northern Powers of Europe still contend, and make great Devastations among the lonocent People of the Empire: Germany feels great Sor∣rows, the Aspect of Things appears dreadful for all Parts of Europe; great Storms, Tempests and violent Rains as well as violent Heats afflict France and Spain, which destroy both their Har∣vest and their Vintage: The Court of France apprehensive of the Plague, but escape this Year: A great Difference happens about this Time be∣tween the Turks and some other European Princes, which threaten another War on that Side, but the Prudence of some Mediators prevent an open Rupture; Muscovy trembles at Turkish Power.

Italy desolated this Season in many Parts by Contagion of Men as well as Cattle, and great Troubles in Naples, occasion'd by the Avarice of the Germans, which are not suppressed without great Ruin and Oppression of the People.

DIV2.HEAD: Ninth VISION.
DIV2.P:
FRom the clearness of our Morning and Even∣ing Exhalations are form'd now a Variety of bright Visions representing Peace, and comfort∣ing Circumstances to Great-Britain, France and Spain, and some other Parts of the World; but by the Operation of our most clear Perception, all appears dark again; towards the latter End of the Year Clouds of Dissention arise in France; perhaps the great Fury, whose Emblem is the Sun
in his full Strength, is now setting; if nor, if Death is not his Portion, at this Time, some Ca∣pital Disappointment shall attend him and his Affairs: Misunderstandings are begun between France and Spain about this time, which in pro∣cess of Years shall divide these two Nations as much as ever, and tho' not in the Life of the present King of France, shall end in a War be∣tween those Two Crowns immediately after, and this War shall embark Europe in new Engage∣ments very differing from what the late War had occasion'd, or the present Peace been form∣ing among us.

I see here the Year closing without a perfect Conclusion of the Peace, but the Expence of a fruitless War on both Sides seems to incline all Parties, even France it self, to a greater readi∣ness to comply. The Emperor has not carried on his Share of the War without eminent Los in the Field, especially in Germany; nor th French without great Expence of Men and Money, his early Expeditions on the Rhine long Marches into Spain, and the excessive Heat there, have harrass'd his Army, and ruin'd his In∣fantry: In Flanders equal Fatigues, and little or no Progress hath attended both Armies, that all seem to incline to Peace, and to set a∣bout it with more Earnestness than ever, ye great Obstructions lie in the Way; I see indeed great Probability that it shall be finally con∣pleated in the Months of September and Octobe but some Accidents may still intervene to pr∣vent it.

Something threatens Italy this Season, and the Death of the Pope, attended with unusual Diffi∣culties threatning a Schism in the Romish Af∣fairs seem the End of things there; the Conduct of the French in these Things will have a great Share, nor will this Year end it.

Mount Vesuvius may have an unusual Irruption about this time also, and some Earthquakes in Sicily are like to do great Damage; Scarcity of Corn in Italy, Spain and Lombardy reduce the Poor to great Extremities.

DIV2.HEAD: Tenth VISION.
DIV2.P: BY what Aspect our usual Appearances have at our Tenth Observation, I see Hopes that the End of the Year closes with Peace, and for that reason I give you but Ten Visions for this Year, whereas before it was in Twelve. The Allies of Britain concluding, or not conclu∣ding, we allow our selves to be in Peace: The General Treaty eminently manag'd by the British Influence, may not yet have effectually been fi∣nished, but the Peace as entertain'd by the Bri∣tish Sovereign, appears made for our selves, and such of our Allies as stand with us; the rest complain loudly, and talk high, but see a Ne∣cessity of Complying, and putting an End to the War which now every Body think better of than they did before.

Many of my Second-Sighted Friends say openly that they see farther than I have done into these Things, which I will not deny; they pretend to see that the Peace was made some time since, with ill Views and ill Prospects, and by ill Men, and will but ill last, and that many ill Conse∣quences shall happen from it; but I shall rather publish my own Views, and what my own Sight discovers, than what these Men say: I cannot say with Verity that I have such black Sights beyond the Peace as they have, and therefore say to my Countrymen and Friends, That if the ill Things do follow the Peace which these Men predict, it must, very much of it, be the Mis-management of our own selves at Home that may procure it, and that therefore, if they please, the Peace shall be well or ill for them: Among those who have it so much in their Power to better to us the Effects of Peace, none so much as those who make it; who, if they will prevent the Influences of France over Affairs in Britain, and in the rest of Europe, questionless may cause the Effects of this Peace to be less hurtful to Britain than o∣therwise it would be: These Men can, no doubt, prevent the Dangers of the Party who favour a Wrong Succession, and can bring the Nation to a more settled Condition in that Affair than we are in at present: Whether they shall do this or not; whether they shall take Effectual Care or no to prevent the Fears of the People, and farther to secure us after a Peace, I shall give a more direct Account of in my next Year's Predictions.

The two last Months of this Year threaten great Loss and Destruction in Europe by unusual Tempests, especially about November, the ga∣thering. Torrents I see evidently in the Air, and all the Heats of Summer furnish Vapour for this Irruption; it is probable the same shall be attend∣ed with great Innundations of Water.

Some great Calamity threatens Germany and Hungary; whether the Northern War shall break out again, or whether the Turks shall fall in upon the Empire, does not yet appear, but it seems that the War in the North, notwithstanding all the Endeavours of the Princes of Germany to put an End to it, shall not be finally concluded during the length of these Predictions.

The Plague, as is usual at this Season of the Year, ceases, or rather takes Breath only to re∣vive with the more Fury, and if my Second Sight says true to me, the next Year it shall begin in these Countries, or entirely cease in EƲROPE.
